description: From the verb hoke (“to give an artificial feel to”), from hokum.

entries.meaning: (US, colloquial) Phony, as if a hoax; noticeably contrived; of obviously flimsy credibility or quality.
examples: When asked for his book report, Chad came up with a series of hokier and hokier excuses.
I thought the windshield wiper blades were a little hokey when I saw their cheap packaging.

entries.meaning: (US, colloquial) Corny; overly or unbelievably sentimental.
examples: Terry hated going to the cinema with Pat, she always chose hokey romantic comedies that made him want to gag.
